docs.snippet: SANTIAGO, Chile -- South America is a vacation land of paradox. For 130 Argentine pesos -- less than $20 over most hotel desks, though not at banks, where it would come to about $27 -- you can make the most celebrated air crossing in the Western...
docs.lead_paragraph: SANTIAGO, Chile -- South America is a vacation land of paradox. For 130 Argentine pesos -- less than $20 over most hotel desks, though not at banks, where it would come to about $27 -- you can make the most celebrated air crossing in the Western World.

headline.main: A WHOLE CONTINENT FOR THE TOURIST; In South America He Will Find All Kinds Of Holidays, and Some Red Tape

docs.snippet: LAKE SUCCESS, May 7 -- A resolution that would allow members of the United Nations to send Ambassadors and Ministers to Spain was approved today in the Political Committee of the General Assembly by a vote of 25 to 16 with sixteen abstentions.

docs.snippet: Foreign exchange traders' attention last week veered sharply to the spectacular rise in the Canadian free dollar which climbed to 95.38 cents, highest since Feb. 24, 1947, thus displacing the pound sterling as the focal point of interest. Friday's...
docs.lead_paragraph: Foreign exchange traders' attention last week veered sharply to the spectacular rise in the Canadian free dollar which climbed to 95.38 cents, highest since Feb. 24, 1947, thus displacing the pound sterling as the focal point of interest. Friday's close on Canadian was 95.32 cents, a gain of 1-1/16 cents over the preceding week.

headline.main: FOREIGN EXCHANGE RATES; Week Ended, May 6, 1949.

docs.snippet: WASHINGTON, May 8 -- The American merchant marine, with less than half the passenger-carrying capacity it had in 1939, faces serious problems in the general upbuilding of competitive fleets, it was shown in an authoritative survey made public here...
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 8 -- The American merchant marine, with less than half the passenger-carrying capacity it had in 1939, faces serious problems in the general upbuilding of competitive fleets, it was shown in an authoritative survey made public here today.

docs.snippet: LAKE SUCCESS, May 9 -- The Ad Hoc Political Committee of the General Assembly approved today a resolution calling for the admission of Israel to the United Nations. The vote was 33 to 11, and thus apparently assured the necessary two-thirds majority...
docs.lead_paragraph: LAKE SUCCESS, May 9 -- The Ad Hoc Political Committee of the General Assembly approved today a resolution calling for the admission of Israel to the United Nations. The vote was 33 to 11, and thus apparently assured the necessary two-thirds majority for the application when the General Assembly takes it up later in the week.
docs.abstract: com rejects Lebanese motion censuring Israeli failure

headline.main: Israel's U.N. Entry Held Sure As Ad Hoc Unit Votes, 33-11; Israel's Entry in U. N. Is Held Sure As Ad Hoc Committee Votes, 33-11

byline.original: By THOMAS J. HAMILTONSpecial to THE NEW YORK TIMES

docs.snippet: LAKE SUCCESS, May 10 -- The special Political Committee of the United Nations General Assembly approved late tonight a Bolivian resolution directing the Economic and Social Council and the Secretary General to investigate conditions of life and work...
docs.lead_paragraph: LAKE SUCCESS, May 10 -- The special Political Committee of the United Nations General Assembly approved late tonight a Bolivian resolution directing the Economic and Social Council and the Secretary General to investigate conditions of life and work among millions of aboriginal inhabitants of Central and South America. The final vote, which came shortly before midnight, was twenty-eight in favor and none against, with nine nations abstaining.
docs.abstract: UN Assembly com approves Bolivian proposal for ECOSOC study of conditions among Latin-Amer aborigines, 28-0; acrid East-West debate revd

headline.main: U. N. GROUP BACKS ABORIGINES STUDY; Economic Council Is Directed to Investigate Life of Indians in South, Central America

docs.snippet: STAMP collectors, first in Sweden, later in England, and more recently in New York, have been hoaxed by "news" that Sweden had scheduled a series of stamps with portraits of members of Sweden's present Cabinet.
docs.lead_paragraph: STAMP collectors, first in Sweden, later in England, and more recently in New York, have been hoaxed by "news" that Sweden had scheduled a series of stamps with portraits of members of Sweden's present Cabinet.

headline.main: NEWS OF THE WORLD OF STAMPS; Report of a New Swedish Series Proves to Be an April Fool Hoax
